home.title: Alzheimer's
home.subtitle: risk factors
home.description: Our platform uses advanced AI to analyze speech and text patterns for early signs of cognitive decline, helping with early detection of Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer's prevention through comprehensive assessment tools.

features.title: Everything you need for cognitive health
features.description: Our platform combines AI-powered analysis, cognitive training, and resources to support your brain health journey.

commonRecommendations.engageActivities: Engage in regular cognitive activities such as puzzles or reading.
commonRecommendations.maintainSocial: Maintain social interactions to stimulate cognitive engagement.
commonRecommendations.periodicAssessments: Consider periodic cognitive assessments to monitor changes over time.
commonRecommendations.memoryExercises: Schedule regular memory exercises (e.g., word recall games).
commonRecommendations.consultNeurologist: Consult a neurologist for baseline cognitive testing.
commonRecommendations.dailyJournal: Maintain a daily journal to track forgetfulness patterns.
commonRecommendations.physicalExercise: Engage in moderate physical exercise to promote brain health.
commonRecommendations.healthyDiet: Follow a brain-healthy diet rich in omega-3 fatty acids.
commonRecommendations.qualitySleep: Ensure 7-9 hours of quality sleep each night.
commonRecommendations.stressManagement: Practice stress management techniques like meditation.
commonRecommendations.mentalStimulation: Engage in mentally stimulating activities daily.
commonRecommendations.socialEngagement: Stay socially active and maintain relationships.
commonRecommendations.regularCheckups: Schedule regular medical checkups and screenings.
commonRecommendations.mindfulnessPractices: Incorporate mindfulness practices to improve attention and focus.

scoreExplanation.title: Understanding Your Cognitive Scores
scoreExplanation.description: These scores reflect how your language patterns compare to typical patterns across five cognitive domains. Higher scores (closer to 100) indicate stronger performance in that domain.
scoreExplanation.vocabularyLow: Your vocabulary usage shows limited range and diversity, which may indicate some language processing challenges.
scoreExplanation.vocabularyModerate: Your vocabulary usage shows a moderate range of words, with room for improvement in lexical diversity.
scoreExplanation.vocabularyHigh: Your vocabulary usage shows excellent diversity and range, indicating strong language processing abilities.
scoreExplanation.sentenceLow: Your sentence structures are primarily simple, which may indicate challenges in organizing complex thoughts.
scoreExplanation.sentenceModerate: Your sentence structures show moderate complexity, with some variety in how ideas are structured and connected.
scoreExplanation.sentenceHigh: Your sentence structures are appropriately complex and varied, indicating strong cognitive organization abilities.
scoreExplanation.fluencyLow: Your expression contains frequent hesitations or repetitions, which may indicate challenges with attention and processing.
scoreExplanation.fluencyModerate: Your expression is moderately fluent with occasional hesitations or topic shifts.
scoreExplanation.fluencyHigh: Your expression is very fluent with minimal hesitations, indicating strong attention and processing abilities.
scoreExplanation.memoryLow: Your descriptions contain limited specific details, which may indicate memory recall challenges.
scoreExplanation.memoryModerate: Your descriptions include moderate detail level with some specific references.
scoreExplanation.memoryHigh: Your descriptions are rich with specific details, indicating strong memory recall abilities.
scoreExplanation.disclaimer: Note: These assessments are based on AI analysis of language patterns and should not replace professional medical evaluation. If you have concerns about cognitive health, please consult a healthcare professional.

wordRecall.title: Word Recall Challenge
wordRecall.description: Memorize and recall a series of words to improve memory performance.

languageFluency.title: Language Fluency Game
languageFluency.description: Generate words that start with a specific letter across different categories.

memoryMatch.title: Memory Match Game
memoryMatch.description: Match question cards with their corresponding answers to improve memory and attention.

categoryNaming.title: Category Naming Game
categoryNaming.description: Name as many items as possible within a specific category to boost semantic fluency.

sequenceOrdering.title: Sequence Ordering Game
sequenceOrdering.description: Arrange shuffled steps in their correct chronological or logical order.

whyItMatters.title: Why Cognitive Training Matters
whyItMatters.description: Regular cognitive training has been shown to support brain health and may help reduce the risk of cognitive decline. These exercises target specific cognitive domains including memory, attention, language, and executive function.
whyItMatters.recommendation: For best results, aim to complete at least 3-4 training sessions per week, varying the types of exercises to challenge different cognitive abilities.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.description: Common misconceptions about Alzheimer's disease and cognitive health, clarified with evidence-based facts.
faq.disclaimerText: This information is for educational purposes only and should not replace professional medical advice. If you have concerns about cognitive health, please consult with a qualified healthcare provider.

item1.misconception: Memory loss is a normal part of aging.
item1.fact: While some mild forgetfulness is common with aging, persistent memory loss that disrupts daily life is not normal. It may be an early sign of Alzheimer's or another type of dementia. Aging-related forgetfulness (e.g., occasionally misplacing keys) differs from forgetting how to use the keys or what they're for.

item2.fact: Most people with Alzheimer's are 65 or older, but early-onset Alzheimer's can develop in people as young as their 30s or 40s. It accounts for about 5–10% of all cases. Younger individuals may initially be misdiagnosed due to atypical symptoms like vision or language problems rather than memory issues.

item3.fact: Alzheimer's affects more than memory—it impairs thinking, problem-solving, language, judgment, and behavior. As it progresses, it can cause confusion, mood swings, personality changes, and loss of independence.

item4.fact: Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) increases the risk of Alzheimer's, but not all people with MCI progress to dementia. Some remain stable for years, and a portion may even revert to normal cognition, especially if the cause is treatable (e.g., medication side effects, depression, or sleep disorders).

item5.misconception: There is no treatment for Alzheimer's.
item5.fact: There is no cure yet, but treatments can manage symptoms and improve quality of life. FDA-approved medications (e.g., donepezil, memantine, lecanemab) may slow progression in early stages. Lifestyle changes, cognitive activities, and social support are also crucial non-pharmacological interventions.

item6.misconception: People with Alzheimer's have no awareness.
item6.fact: In early and even moderate stages, many individuals are aware of their diagnosis and capable of participating in decisions. Lack of understanding from others can lead to social withdrawal and unnecessary dependence.

item7.misconception: Alzheimer's is caused by aluminum, vaccines, or microwaves.
item7.fact: These claims are not supported by scientific evidence. Alzheimer's is caused by a complex interplay of genetics, age, vascular health, and lifestyle factors—not by everyday exposures like cooking with aluminum or using vaccines.

item8.misconception: Dementia and Alzheimer's are the same.
item8.fact: Dementia is a general term for cognitive decline affecting daily life. Alzheimer's is the most common cause of dementia, but there are others, including vascular dementia, Lewy body dementia, and frontotemporal dementia.

item9.misconception: People with dementia cannot understand or communicate.
item9.fact: People with dementia often retain emotional memory and the ability to respond to kindness, tone of voice, music, and visual cues. With patience and adaptation, meaningful communication is often possible far into the disease.

item10.misconception: A person with Alzheimer's cannot live well.
item10.fact: With the right support, routines, and engagement in activities they enjoy, many people with Alzheimer's continue to experience joy, connection, and purpose—especially in early and middle stages.
